newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Too few doctors to treat wounded Afghan warriors.
newsitem.headline: Too few doctors to treat wounded Afghan warriors.

text.p: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) on Sunday evacuated about 25 Afghan rebels badly wounded in frontline fighting for control of the capital Kabul.
The evacuation was carried out as concern grew about a shortage of doctors to care for the wounded on both sides in the figtht.

An ICRC road convoy carrying the wounded took them to the strategic highway town of Pul-i-Khumri, a six-hour drive from where the so-called Northern Alliance are fighting some 20 km (12 miles) from Kabul against the nominal government of the Islamic fundamentalist Taleban movement.
Wounded who could not be treated even at Pul-i-Khumri would be taken further back to Mazar-i-Sharif, the rear headquarters of the alliance.
Several doctors from Pul-i-Khumri were sent to the front line to help care for the wounded and to prepare for more casualties in the days ahead, when fighting is expected to reach a new pitch.
"There is a shortage of doctors on both sides, there is a lot of concern about," Baghlan province governor Syed Jafar told reporters.
Jafar said the fighting was cutting off routes for doctors to get to wounded both from troops of the alliance and the Taleban.
The Taleban in Kabul have banned women from doing some medical jobs, draining the pool of doctors and medical workers.
The alliance's chief military commander Ahmad Shah Masood on Sunday called a meeting in Gulbahar of frontline commanders for a pep talk and discussion of how to break the stalemate in fighting.
Masood launched a nationwide assault nearly two weeks ago to break the Taleban's grip on the capital they captured last September.
After swift advances, the drive appears to have stalled over the last few days in the face of strong Taleban counter-attacks, some of them mounted across minefields.
